publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter two Serving-men, Peter and Anthony.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: I Would we were remov'd from this Town, Anthony
That we might taste some quiet: for mine owne part,
I'me almost melted with continuall trotting
After enquiries, dreames, and revelations,
Of who knowes, whom or where? serve wenching soldiers,
That know no other Paradice but Plackets:
Ile serve a Priest in Lent, first and eate Bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thou art the froward'st foole—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why good tame Anthony?
Tell me but this: to what end came we hither?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To wait upon our Masters.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: But how Anthony?
Answer me that; resolve me there good Anthony?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To serve their uses.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Shew your uses Anthony.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To be imploy'd in any thing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No Anthony,
Not any thing I take it; nor that thing
We travell to discover, like new Islands;
A salt itch serve such uses; in things of moment,
Concerning things I grant yee, not things errant,
Sweet Ladies things, and things to thank the Surgeon:
In no such things, sweet Anthony, put case—

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Come, come, all will be mended: this invisible woman
Of infinite report for shape and vertue,
That bred us all this trouble to no purpose,
They are determin'd now no more to thinke on,
But fall close to their studies.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Was there ever
Men knowne to run mad with report before?
Or wonder after that they know not where
To finde? or if found, how to enjoy? are mens braines
Made now a dayes of Malt, that their affections
Are never sober? but like drunken people
Founder at every new fame? I do believe too
That men in love are ever drunke, as drunken men
Are ever loving.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Prethee be thou sober,
And know, that they are none of those, not guilty
Of the least vanity of love, onely a doubt
Fame might too farre report, or rather flatter
The graces of this woman, made them curious
To finde the truth, which since they finde so blotted
And lock'd up from their searches, they are now setled
To give the wonder ever.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Would they were setled
To give me some new shooes too: for I'le be sworne
These are e'ne worne out to the reasonable soules
In their good worships businesse: and some sleep
Would not doe much amisse, unlesse they meane
To make a Bell-man on me: and what now
Meane they to study, Anthony, Morall Philosophy
After their mar-all women?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Mar a fooles head.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twill mar two fools heads, & they take not heed,
Besides the Giblets to 'em.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Will you walke Sir,
And talke more out of hearing? your fooles head
May chance to finde a wooden night-cap else.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I never lay in any. Enter Don John and Fredrick.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then leave your lying,
And your blinde Prophesying: here they come,
You had best tell them as much.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am no tell-tale. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I would we could have seen her though: for sure
She must be some rare creature, or report lyes,
All mens reports too,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I could well wish I had seen her;
But since she is so conceal'd, so beyond venture
Kept and preserv'd from view, so like a Paradice,
Plac't where no knowledg can come near her; so guarded
As 'twere impossible, though knowne to reach her,
I have made up my beliefe.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hang me from this houre
If I more thinke upon her, or believe her,
But as she came a strong report unto me,
So the next Fame shall loose her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis the next way:
But whither are you walking?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: My old round
After my meat, and then to bed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis healthfull.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Will not you stir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have a little businesse.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Upon my life this Lady still—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Then you will loose it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Pray let's walke together.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now I cannot.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I have something to impart.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: An houre hence
I will not misse to meet you.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: ith' high street;
For not to lye, I have a few Devotions
To doe first, then I am yours.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Remember. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Antonio, and two Gent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cut his winde-pipe, I say.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Fie Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Or knock his brains out first, then forgive him
If you doe thrust, be sure it be to th' hilts,
A Surgeon may see through him.
You are too violent,
Too open, undiscreet.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Am I not ruin'd?
The honour of my house crack'd? my bloud poyson'd?
My credit, and my name?
Be sure it be so,
Before ye use this violence. Let not doubt,
And a suspecting anger so much sway ye,
Your wisedome may be question'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I say kill him,
And then dispute the cause; cut off what may be,
And what is, shall be safe.
Hang up a true man,
Because 'tis possible he may be theevish:
Alas, is this good Justice?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I know as certaine,
As day must come againe; as cleare as truth.
And open as beliefe can lay it to me,
That I am basely wrong'd, wrong'd above recompence;
Malitiously abus'd, blasted for ever
In name and honour, lost to all remembrance,
But what is smear'd, and shamefull; I must kill him,
Necessitie compells me.
But think better

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: There is no other cure left: yet witnesse with me
All that is faire in man, all that is noble,
I am not greedy of this life I seek for,
Nor thirst to shed mans bloud; and would 'twere possible
I wish it with my soule, so much I tremble
To offend the sacred Image of my Maker,
My sword could onely kill his crimes: no 'tis honour,
Honour, my noble friends, that idoll honour,
That all the world now worships, not Petruchio
Must doe this justice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it once be done,
And 'tis no matter, whether you, or honour,
Or both be accessarie.
Doe you weigh Petruchio
The value of the person, power, and greatnesse,
And what this sparke may kindle?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To performe it,
So much I am ty'd to reputation,
And credit of my house, let it raise wild-fires,
That all this Dukedome smoak, and stormes that tosse me
Into the stormes of everlasting ruine,
Yet I must through; if yee dare side me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dare?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Ye're friends indeed, if not.
Here's none flies from you,
Doe it in what designe ye please, wee'll back ye.
But then be sure yee kill him.
Is the cause
So mortall, nothing but his life?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Beleeve me,
A lesse offence has been the desolation
Of a whole name.
No other way to purge it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: There is, but never to be hoped for,
Thinke an houre more,
And if then ye finde no safer road to guide yee,
Wee'll set up our rests too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Mine's up already,
And hang him for my part,
Goes lesse than life.
If we see noble cause, 'tis like our swords
May be as free and forward as your words. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The civill order of this Towne Bellonia
Makes it belov'd, and honour'd of all travellers,
As a most safe retirement in all troubles;
Beside the wholsome seat, and noble temper
Of those mindes that inhabit it, safely wise,
And to all strangers vertuous: But I see
My admiration has drawne night upon me,
And longer to expect my friend may pull me
Into suspition of too late a stirrer,
Which all good Governments are jealous of.
Ile home, and thinke at liberty: yet certaine,
'Tis not so farre night as I thought; for see,
A faire house yet stands open, yet all about it
Are close, and no lights stirring: there may be foule play:
Ile venture to look in: if there be knaves,
I may doe a good office. Woman within.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Signieur?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: What? how is this?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Signieur Fabritio?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Ile goe nearer.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Fabritio?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: This is a womans tongue, here may be good done.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Who's there?
Fabritio?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Where are ye?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: O come, for heavens sake!

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I must see what this meanes,

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I have stay'd this long houre for you, make no noise,
For things are in strange trouble: here, be secret,
'Tis worth your care; begone now; more eyes watch us,
Then may be for our safeties.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Harke ye?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Peace: good night.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: She is gone, and I am loaden; fortune for me;
It weighes well, and it feeles well; it may chance
To be some pack of worth: by th' masse 'tis heavie;
If it be Coyne or Jewels, 'tis worth welcome:
Ile ne're refuse a fortune: I am confident
'Tis of no common price: now to my lodging:
If it hit right, Ile blesse this night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis strange,
I cannot meet him; sure he has encountred
Some light o' love or other, and there meanes
To play at In and In for this night. Well Don John,
If you doe spring a leak, or get an itch,
Til ye claw off your curl'd pate, thank your night-walks:
You must be still a bootehaling: one round more,
Though it be late, Ile venture to discover ye,
I doe not like your out-leaps.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Welcome to Towne, are ye all fit?
To point Sir,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where are the horses?
Where they were appointed.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Be private, and whatsoever fortune
Offer it selfe, let's stand sure.
Feare not us,
'Ere ye shall be endangered, or deluded,
Wee'll make a black night on't.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more, I know it;
You know your Quarters?
Will you goe alone sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ye shall not be farre from me, the least noise
Shall bring ye to my rescue.
We are counsell'd. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Was ever man so paid for being curious?
Ever so bob'd for searching out adventures,
As I am? did the devill lead me? must I needs be peeping
Into mens houses where I had no businesse,
And make my selfe a mischiefe? 'Tis well carried;
I must take other mens occasions on me,
And be I know not whom: most finely handled:
What have I got by this now? what's the purchase?
A piece of evening Arras worke, a childe,
Indeed an Infidell: this comes of peeping:
A lumpe got out of lazinesse; good white bread
Let's have no bawling with yee: 'sdeath, have I
Knowne Wenches thus long, all the wayes of wenches,
Their snares and subtilties? have I read over
All their Schoole learnings, div'd into their quiddits,
And am I now bum-fidled with a Bastard?
Fetch'd over with a Carde of five, and in mine old dayes,
After the dire massacre of a million
Of Maiden-heads? caught the common way, ith' night too
Under anothers name, to make the matter
Carry more weight about it? well Don Iohn,
You will be wiser one day, when ye have purchas'd
A beavy of these Butter prints together,
With searching out conceal'd iniquities,
Without commission: why, it would never grieve me,
If I had got this Ginger-bread: never stirr'd me,
So I had had a stroak for't: 't had been Justice
Then to have kept it; but to raise a dayrie
For other mens adulteries, consume my selfe in candles,
And scowring works, in Nurses Bells and Babies,
Onely for charity, for meere I thank you,
A little troubles me: the least touch for it,
Had but my breeches got it, had contented me.
Whose e're it is, sure t' had a wealthy mother,
For 'tis well cloathed, and if I be not cozen'd,
Well lin'd within: to leave it here were barbarous,
And ten to one would kill it: a more sin
Then his that got it: well, I will dispose on't,
And keep it, as they keep deaths heads in rings,
To cry, memento to me; no more peeping.
Now all the danger is to qualifie
The good old gentlewoman, at whose house we live,
For she will fall upon me with a Catechisme
Of foure houres long: I must endure all;
For I will know this mother: Come good wonder,
Let you and I be jogging: your starv'd trebble
Will waken the rude watch else: All that bee
Curious night-walkers, may they finde my fee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sure hee's gone home:
I have beaten all the purlewes,
But cannot bolt him: if he be a bobbing
'Tis not my care can cure him: To morrow morning
I shall have further knowledge from a Surgeons—
Where he lyes moord, to mend his leaks.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: I'me ready,
And through a world of dangers am flown to yee.
Be full of haste and care, we are undone else:
Where are your people? which way must we travell?
For heaven sake stay not here sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What may this prove?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Alas I am mistaken, lost, undone.
For ever perish'd. Sir, for heaven sake tell me,
Are ye a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Of this place?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, borne in Spain.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As ever you lov'd honour,
As ever your desires may gaine their ends,
Doe a poore wretched woman but this benefit,
For I am forc'd to trust yee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Y'ave charm'd me,
Humanity and honour bids me helpe ye;
And if I faile your trust.—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The time's too dangerous
To stay your protestations: I beleeve ye,
Alas, I must believe ye: From this place,
Good noble Sir, remove me instantly,
And for a time, where nothing but your selfe,
And honest conversation may come neare me,
In some secure place settle me. What I am,
And why thus boldly I commit my credit
Into a strangers hand, the feares and dangers,
That force me to this wilde course, at more leisure
I shall reveale unto you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come, be hearty,
He must strike through my life that takes ye from me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He will sure come. Are yee well arm'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Never feare us.
Here's that will make 'em dance without a Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: We are to look for no weak foes, my friends,
Nor unadvised ones.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Best gamsters make the best game,
We shall fight close and handsome then.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Antonio,
You are a thought too bloudy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? all Physitians
And penny Almanacks allow the opening
Of veines this moneth: why doe ye talke of bloudy?
What come we for, to fall to cuffes for apples?
What, would ye make the Cause a Cudgell quarell?
On what termes stands this man? is not his honour
Open'd to his hand, and pickt out like an Oyster?
His credit like a quart pot knockt together,
Able to hold no liquor? cleare but this point.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Speak softly, gentle Couzen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile speak truely;
What should men doe ally'd to these disgraces,
Lick o're his enemie, sit downe, and dance him?
You are as farre o'th' bow hand now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And crie;
That's my fine boy, thou wilt doe so no more child.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Here are no such cold pitties.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Saint Jaques
They shall not finde me one: here's old tough Andrew,
A speciall friend of mine, and he but hold,
He strike 'em such a horne-pipe: knocks I come for,
And the best bloud I light on; I profes it,
Not to scarre Coster-mongers; If I loose mine owne,
Mine audits lost, and fare-well five and fifty.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Let's talke no longer, place your selves with silence,
As I directed yee; and when time calls us,
As ye are friends, so shew your selves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So be it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. 9.
div.stage: Enter Don John and his Land-lady.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Nay Son, if this be your regard.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Good mother.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Good me no goods; your Cozen, and your self
Are welcome to me, whilst you beare your selves
Like honest and true Gentlemen: Bring hither
To my house, that have ever been reputed
A gentlewoman of a decent, and faire carriage,
And so behav'd my self?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I know ye have.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bring hither, as I say, to make my name
Stinke in my neighbours nostrills? your Devises,
Your Brats, got out of Alligant, and broken oathes?
Your Linsey Woolsey worke, your hasty puddings?
I fosler up your filch'd iniquities?
Y'are deceiv'd in me, Sir, I am none
Of those receivers.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Have I not sworne unto you,
'Tis none of mine, and shew'd you how I found it?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Ye found an easie foole that let you get it,
She had better have worne pastornes.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Will yee heare me?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Oathes? what doe you care for oathes to gaine your ends,
When ye are high and pamper'd? What Saint know ye?
Or what Religion, but your purpos'd lewdnesse,
Is to be look'd for of ye? nay, I will tell ye,
You will then sweare like accus'd Cut-purses,
As far of truth too; and lye beyond all Faulconers:
I'me sick to see this dealing.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Heaven forbid Mother.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Nay, I am very sick.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir. within.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Bring down the bottle of Canary wine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Exceeding sick, heav'n helpe me.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Haste ye sirrah,
I must ev'n make her drunk; nay gentle mother;

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now fie upon ye, was it for this purpose
You fetch'd your evening walks for your digestions,
For this pretended holinesse? no weather,
Not before day could hold ye from the Matins.
Were these your bo-peep prayers? ye have praid well,
And with a learned zeale: watcht well too; your Saint
It seems was pleas'd as well: still sicker, sicker.
sp.stage: Enter Anthony with a bottle of wine.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There is no talking to her till I have drencht her.
Give me: here mother take a good round draught,
'Twill purge spleen from your spirits: deeper mother.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I, I, sonne; you imagine this will mend all.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: All y'faith Mother.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I confesse the Wine
Will doe his part.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Ile pledge ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But sonne John.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I know your meaning mother; touch it once more,
Alas you look not well; take a round draught,
It warmes the bloud well, and restores the colour,
And then wee'll talke at large.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: A civill gentleman?
A stranger? one the Town holds a good regard of?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Nay I will silence there.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: One that should weigh his faire name? oh, a stichl

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There's nothing better for a stitch, good mother,
Make no spare of it, as you love your health,
Mince not the nutter.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: As I said, a gentleman,
Lodge in my house? now heav'ns my comfort, Signior!

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I look'd for this.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I did not thinke you would have us'd me thus;
A woman of my credit: one, heaven knowes,
That lov'd you but too tenderly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Deare mother,
I ever found your kindnesse, and acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No, no, I am a fool to counsell yee. Where's the infant?
Come, lets see your Workmanship.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: None of mine, Mother.
But there 'tis, and a lusty one.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Heaven blesse thee,
Thou hadst a hasty making; but the best is,
'Tis many a good mans fortune: as I live
Your owne eyes Signior, and the nether lip
As like yee, as ye had spit it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Blesse me, what things are these?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I thought my labour
Was not all lost, 'tis gold, & these are jewels,
Both rich, and right I hope.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Well, well sonne Iohn,
I see ye are a wood-man, and can chuse
Your Deere, though it be i'th darke, all your discretion
Is not yet lost; this was well clapt aboard:
Here I am with you now; when as they say
Your pleasure comes with profit; when ye must needs do,
Doe where ye may be done to, 'tis a wisedome
Becomes a young man well: be sure of one thing,
Loose not your labour and your time together,
It seasons of a foole, sonne, time is pretious,
Worke wary whilst ye have it; since ye must traffick
Sometimes this slippery way, take sure hold Signior,
Trade with no broken Merchants, make your lading,
As you would make your rest, adventurously,
But with advantage ever.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: All this time mother,
The childe wants looking too, wants meat and Nurses.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now blessing o' thy care; it shall have all,
And instantly; Ile seek a Nurse my selfe, sonne;
'Tis a sweet childe: ah my young Spaniard;
Take you no further care sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Yes of these Jewels,
I must by your leave Mother: these are yours,
To make your care the stronger: for the rest
Ile finde a Master; the gold for bringing up on't,
I freely render to your charge.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No more words,
Nor no more children, (good sonne) as you love me,
This may doe well.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I shall observe your Morals.
But where's Don Ferdinand (Mother)

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ten to one
About the like adventure: he told me.
He was to finde you out. Exit.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why should he stay thus?
There may be some ill chance in't: sleep I will not,
Before I have found him: now this woman's pleas'd,
Ile seek my friend out, and my care is eas'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Beleeve sir, 'tis as possible to doe it,
As to remove the City; the maine faction,
Swarm throgh the streets like hornets, arm'd with angers
Able to ruine States: no safety left us,
Nor meanes to dye like men, if instantly
You draw not back againe,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: May he be drawne
And quarter'd too, that turnes now; were I surer
Of death then thou art of thy fears, and with death
More then those feares are too.
Sir, I feare not.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I would not crack my vow, start from my honour,
Because I may finde danger; wound my soule,
To keep my body safe.
I speak not sir,
Out of a basenesse to you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No, nor doe not
Out of a basenesse leave mo: what is danger,
More then the weaknesse of our apprehensions?
A poor cold part o'th bloud? who takes it hold of?
Cowards, and wicked livers: valiant mindes
Were made the Masters of it, and as hearty Seamen
In desperate stormes, stem with a little Rudder
The tumbling ruines of the Ocean:
So with their cause & swords do they do dangers.
Say we yere sure to dye all in this venture,
As I am confident against it: is there any
Amongst us of so fat a sense, so pamper'd,
Would chuse luxuriously to lye a bed,
And purge away his spirit, send his soule out
In Sugar-lops, and Syrups? give me dying,
As dying out to be, upon mine enemy,
Parting with man-kinde, by a man that's manly:
Let 'em be all the world, and bring along
Cain's envy with 'em, I will on.
You may sir,
But with what safety?
Since 'tis come to dying,
You shall perceive sir, here be those amongst us
Can dye as decently as other men,
And with as little ceremony: on brave sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: That's spoken heartily.
And he that flinches
May he dye lowzie in a ditch.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more dying,
There's no such danger in it:
What's a clock?
Somewhat above your houre.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Away then quickly,
Make no noise, and no trouble will attend us. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. 11.
div.stage: Enter Fredericke, and Peter, (with a candle.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Give me the candle: so goe you out that way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What have we now to doe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And o' your life sirrah,
Let none come neare the doore without my knowledge,
No not my Land lady, nor my friend.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nor any serious businesse that concerns me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Is the winde there agen?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now enter without feare.— And noble Lady
That safety and civility yee wish'd for
Shall truely here attend you: no rude tongue
Nor rough behaviour knows this place, no wishes
Beyond the moderation of a man,
Dare enter here: your owne desires and Innocence,
Joyn'd to my vow'd obedience, shall protect you,
Were dangers more then doubts.

sp.speaker: Coast.
sp.l: Ye are truely noble,
And worth a womans trust: let it become me,
(I doe beseech you sir) for all your kindnesse,
To render with my thanks, this worthlesse trifle;
I may be longer troublesome.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Faire offices
Are still their owne rewards: Heav'n blesse me Lady
From selling civill courtesies: may it please ye,
If ye will force a favour to oblige me,
Draw but that cloud aside, to satisfie me
For what good Angel I am engag'd,

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: It shall be.
For I am truely confident yee are honest:
The Piece is scarce worth looking on.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Trust me
The abstract of all beauty, soule of sweetnesse,
Defend me honest thoughts, I shall grow wilde else:
What eyes are there, rather what little heavens,
To stirre mens contemplations? what a Paradice
Runs through each part she has? good bloud be temperate:
I must look off: too excellent an object
Confounds the sense that sees it Noble Lady,
If there be any further service to cast on me,
Let it be worth my life, so much I honour ye,
Or the engagement of whole Families.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Your service is too liberall, worthy sir,
Thus farre I shall entreat.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Command me Lady.
You make your power too poore.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: That presently
With all convenient haste, you would retire
Unto the street you found me in.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: There, if you finde a gentleman opprest
With force and violence, doe a mans office,
And draw your sword to rescue him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hee's safe,
Be what he will, and let his foes be devills,
Arm'd with your pitty, I shall conjure 'em.
Retire, this key will guide ye: all things necessary
Are there before ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: All my prayers goe with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye clap on proof upon me: men say gold
Do's all, engages all, works through all dangers:
Now I say beauty can do more: The Kings Exchequer,
Nor all his wealthy Indies, could not draw me
Through halfe those miseries this peece of pleasure
Might make me leap into: we are all like sea-Cards,
All our endeavours and our motions,
(As they doe to the North) still point at beauty,
Still at the fairest: for a handsome woman,
(Setting my soule a side) it should goe hard,
But I would straine my body: yet to her,
Unlesse it be her owne free gratitude,
Hopes ye shall dye, and thou tongue rot within me,
E're I infringe my faith: now to my rescue. Exit.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, pursued by Petruchio, Antonio, and that Faction.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: YOu will not all oppresse me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Kill him ith' wanton eye: let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then yee shall buy me dearely.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Say you so sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I say cut his Wezand spoile his peeping.
Have at your love-sick heart sir. Enter Don John.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Sure 'tis fighting.
My friend may be engag'd: fie gentlemen,
This is unmanly oddes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ile stop your mouth sir. Du. fals down, Don Ioh. bestrides him.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Nay, then have at thee freely:
Ther's a plumb sir to satisfie your longing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Away: I hope I have sped him: here comes rescue.
We shall be endangered: where's Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must have one thrust more sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Come up to me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A mischiefe confound your fingers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well:
Ha's giv'n me my quiet us est, I felt him
In my small guts, I'me sure, has feez'd me:
This comes of siding with ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Can you goe sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I should goe man, and my head were of,
Never talke of going.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come, all shall be well then. Enter the Dukes Faction.
I heare more rescue comming.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let's turne back then;
My skull's uncloven yet, let me but kill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Away for heaven sake with him.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: How is't?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well sir,
Onely a little stagger'd.

sp.speaker: Faction Du.
sp.l: Lets pursue 'em.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No not a man, I charge ye: thanks good coat,
Thou hast sav'd me a shrewd welcome: 't was put home too,
With a good minde I'me sure on't.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Are ye safe then?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My thanks to you brave sir, whose timely valour,
And manly courtesie came to my rescue,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ye 'had foule play offer'd ye, and shame befall him
That can passe by oppression.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May I crave sir,
But thus much honour more, to know your name?
And him I am so bound to?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: For the Bond sir,
'Tis every good mans tye: to know me further
Will little profit ye; I am a stranger,
My Countrey Spaine; my name Don Iohn, a gentleman
That lyes here for my study.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I have heard sir,
Much worthy mention of ye, yet I finde
Fame short of what ye are.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: You are pleas'd sir,
To expresse your courtesie: may I demand
As freely what you are, and what mischance
Cast you into this danger?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: For this present
I must desire your pardon: you shall know me
Ere it be long sir, and a nobler thanks,
Then now my will can render.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Your will's your owne sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is't you look for sir, have yee lost any thing?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Onely my hat i'th scuffle; sure these fellowes
Were night-snaps.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No, believe sir: pray ye use mine,
For 'twil be hard to finde your owne now.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Indeed ye shall, I can command another:
I doe beseech ye honour me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I will sir,
And so Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Within these few dayes
I hope I shall be happy in your knowledge.
Till when I love your memory. Exit Duke, &c. Enter Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I yours.
This is some noble fellow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis his tongue sure.
Don Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Don Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye 'are fairely met sir:
I thought ye had been a Bat-fowling: prethee tell me,
What Revelations hast thou had to night,
That home was never thought of?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Revelations?
Ile tell thee Fredrick. but before I tell thee,
Settle thy understanding.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis prepar'd, sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why then mark what shall follow. This night Fredr.
This bawdy night.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I thought no lesse.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: This blinde night,
What dost think I have got?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Pox it may be.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Would 'twere no worse: ye talke of Revelations,
I have got a Revelation will reveale me,
An arrant Coxcombe while I live.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What is't?
Thou hast lost nothing?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No, I have got I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What hast thou got?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: One of the Infantry, a childe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A chopping child, man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Give ye joy, sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A lump of lewdnesse Fredrick, that's the truth on't:
This Town's abominable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I still told ye Iohn
Your whoring must come home; I counsell'd ye:
But where no grace is—

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: 'Tis none o'mine, man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Answer the Parish so.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Cheated introth.
Peeping into a house, by whom I know not,
Nor where to find the place agen: no Fredricke,
Had I but kist the ring fort; 'tis no poor one,
That's my best comfort, for't has brought about it
Enough to make it man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: At home.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A saving voyage: But what will you say Signior,
To him that searching out your serious Worship,
Has met a stranger fortune?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: How, good Frederick?
A militant girle now to this boy would hit it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, mine's a nobler venture: What do you think Sir
Of a distressed Lady, one whose beauty
Would oversell all Italy?

sp.speaker: Joh,
sp.l: Where is she—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A woman of that rare behaviour,
So qualified, as admiration
Dwels round about her: of that perfect spirit—

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I marry Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That admirable carriage,
That sweetnes in discourse; young as the morning,
Her blushes staining his.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: But where's this Creature?
Shew me but that.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That's all one, shee's forth comming,
I have her sure Boy.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Harke ye Fredrick.
What truck betwixt my Infant?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis too light Sir,
Stick to your charges good Don John, I am well.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: But is there such a wench?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: First tell me this,
Did ye not lately as ye walk'd along,
Discover people that were arm'd, and likely
To doe offence?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Yes mary, and they urg'd it
As far as they had spirit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pray goe forward.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A Gentleman I found ingag'd amongst e'm,
It seemes of noble breeding, I'm sure brave mettall,
As I return'd to looke you, I set in to him,
And without hurt (I thanke heaven) rescued him,
And came my selfe off safe too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My work's done then:
And now to satisfie you, there is a woman,
Oh Iohn, there is a woman—

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Oh, where is she?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And one of no lesse worth then I assure ye;
And which is more, falne under my protection.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I am glad of that: forward sweet Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And which is more then that, by this nights wandring,
And which is most of all, she is at home too Sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Come, lets be gone then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, but 'tis most certaine,
You cannot see her, Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She has sworne me
That none else shall come neare her: not my Mother
Till some few doubts are clear'd.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Not look upon her? What chamber is she in?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: In ours.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Let's goe I say:
A womans oathes are wafers, breake with making,
They must for modestie a litle: we all know it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, I'le assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Not see her?
I smell an old dog trick of yours, well Fredrick,
Ye talkt to me of whoring, let's have faire play,
Square dealing I would wish ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: When 'tis come.
Which I know never will be, to that issue,
Your spoone shall be as deep as mine Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Tell me,
And tell me true, is the cause honourable,
Or for your ease?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: By all our friendship, Iohn,
'Tis honest, and of great end.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I am answer'd:
But let me see her though: leave the doore open
As yee goe in.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not wide open,
But just so, as a jealous husband
Would levell at his wanton wife through.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: That courtesie,
If ye desire no more, and keep it strictly,
I dare afford yee: come, 'tis now neare morning. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 2.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay the old woman's gone too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shee's a Catterwauling
Among the gutters: But conceive me, Peter,
Where our good Masters should be?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where they should be,
I doe conceive, but where they are, good Anthony—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I, there it goes: my Masters bo-peep with me,
With his slye popping in and out agen,
Argued a cause, a frippery cause.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Beleeve me,
They bear up with some carvell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I doe believe thee,
For thou hast such a Master for that chase,
That till he spend his maine Mast—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pray remember
Your courtesie good Anthony; and withall,
How long 'tis since your Master sprung a leak,
He had a sound one since he came. Lute sounds within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Harke.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doest not hear a Lute?
Agen?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Above in my Masters chamber.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: There's no creature: he hath the key himself man.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: This is his Lute: let him have it. Sing within a little.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I grant you; but who strikes it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: An admirable voice too, harke ye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Anthony,
Art sure we are at home?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Without all doubt, Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then this must be the Devill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it be. Sing agen.
Good Devill sing againe: O dainty devill,
Peter beleve it, a most delicate devill,
The sweetest Devill— Enter Fredrick & Don Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If ye could leave peeping.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I cannot by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Then come in softly,
And as ye love your faith, presume no further
Then yee have promised.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Basto.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What make you up so early sir?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: You sir in your contemplations.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O pray ye peace sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why peace sir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: 'Tis your Lute.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pray yee speak softly.
She's playing on't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The house is haunted sir,
For this we have heard this halfe yeare.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye saw nothing;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor I Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Get us our breakfast then,
And make no words on't; wee'll undertake this spirit,
If it be one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is no devill Peter. Sing. Exeunt Servants.
Mum, there be Bats abroad.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stay, now she sings.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: An Angels voice Ile sweare.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why did'st thou shrug so?
Either allay this heat; or as I live
I will not trust ye.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Passe: I warrant ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To curse those starres, that men say governe us,
To raile at fortune, fall out with my Fate,
And taske the generall world, will helpe me nothing:
Alas, I am the same still, neither are they
Subject to helpes, or hurts: Our owne desires
Are our owne fates, our owne stars, all our fortunes,
Which as we sway 'em, so abuse, or blesse us.

div.stage: Enter Fredrick, and Don John peeping.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace to your meditations.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Pox upon ye,
Stand out oth' light.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I crave your mercy sir,
My minde o're-charg'd with care made me unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pray yee set that minde at rest, all shall be perfect.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I like the body rare; a handsome body,
A wondrous handsome body: would she would turne:
See, and that spightfull puppy be not got
Between me and my light againe,

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Tis done,
As all that you command shall bee: the gentleman
Is safely off all danger.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: O de dios.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: How shall I thank ye sir? how satisfie?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Speak softly, gentle Lady, all's rewarded,
Now does he melt like Marmalad.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis certaine,
Thou art the sweetest woman I e're look'd on:
I hope thou art not honest.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: None disturb'd yee?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Not any sir, nor any sound came neare me,
I thank your care.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I would faine pray now,
But the Devill and that flesh there, o' the world,
What are we made to suffer?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Hee'll enter;
Pull in your head and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Harke ye Fredricke,
I have brought ye home your Pack-saddle.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pox upon yee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Nay let him enter: fie my Lord the Duke,
Stand peeping at your friends.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ye are cozen'd Lady,
Here is no Duke.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I know him full well Signior.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Hold thee there wench.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: This mad-brain'd foole will spoile all.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I doe beseech your grace come in.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: My Grace,
There was a word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Shall he enter,
Who e're he be?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Well follow'd Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come in then. Enter Don John.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: 'Blesse yee Lady:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay start not, though he be a stranger to ye,
Hee's of a Noble straine, my kinsman, Lady,
My Countrey-man, and fellow Traveller,
One bed containes us ever, one purse feeds us,
And one faith free between us; do not fear him,
Hee's truely honest.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: That's a lye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And trusty:
Beyond your wishes: valiant to defend,
And modest to converse with, as your blushes.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now may I hang my self; this commendation
Has broke the neck of all my hopes: for now
Must I cry, no forsooth, and I forsooth, and surely,
And truely as I live, and as I am honest.
Has done these things for 'nonce too; for hee knowes,
Like a most envious Rascall as he is,
I am not honest, nor desire to be,
Especially this way: h'as watch'd his time,
But I shall quit him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Sir, I credit ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Goe kisse her John.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Plague o' your commendations.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, I shall now desire to be a trouble.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Never to me, sweet Lady: Thus I seale
My faith, and all my service.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: One word Signeur.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now 'tis impossible I should be honest,
She kisses with a conjuration
Would make the devill dance: what points she at?
My leg I warrant, or my well knit body:
Sit fast Don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Twas given him by that gentleman
You took such care of; his owne being lost ith' scuffle.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With much joy may he weare it: 'tis a right one,
I can assure ye Gentleman, and right happy
May you be in all fights for that faire service.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why doe ye blush?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'T had almost cozen'd me,
For not to lye, when I saw that, I look'd for
Another Master of it: but 'tis well. Knock within.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who's there? Ent. Anthony.
Stand ye a little close: Come in Sir,
Now what's the newes with you?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: There is a gentleman without,
Would speak with Don John,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Who sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do not know Sir, but he shews a man
Of no meane reckoning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let him shew his name,
And then returne a little wiser.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well Sir. Exit Anthony.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How doe you like her Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: As well as you Fredrick,
For all I am honest: you shall finde it so too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Art thou not honest?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Art thou an Asse?
And modest as her blushes? What a block-head
Would e're have popt out such a dry Apologie,
For his deare friend? and to a Gentlewoman,
A woman of her youth, and delicacy.
They are arguments to draw them to abhorre us.
An honest morall man; 'tis for a Constable:
A handsome man, a wholsome man, a tough man,
A liberall man, a likely man, a man
Made up like Hercules, unslak'd with service:
The same to night, to morrow night, the next night,
And so to perpetuitie of pleasures,
These had been things to hearken too, things catching:
But you have such a spiced consideration,
Such qualmes upon your worships conscience,
Such- chil-blaines in your bloud, that all things pinch ye,
Which nature, and the liberall world makes custome,
And nothing but faire honour, O sweet honour,
Hang up your Eunuch honour: That I was trusty,
And valiant, were things well put in; but modest!
A modest gentleman I ô wit where wast thou?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am sorrie John,

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: My Ladies gentlewoman
Would laugh me to a Schoole-boy, make me blush
With playing with my Codpeece point: fie on thee,
A man of thy discretion?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It shall be mended:
And henceforth yee shall have your due. Enter Anthony.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I look fort: How now, who is't?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: A gentleman of this towne
And calls himselfe Petruchio. Enter Constantia.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Ile attend him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: How did he call himselfe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Petruchio,
Doe's it concerne you ought?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O gentlemen,
The houre of my destruction is come on me,
I am discover'd, lost, left to my ruine:
As ever ye had pitty—

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Doe not feare,
Let the great devill come, he shall come through me:
Lost here, and we about ye?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fall before us?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: O my unfortunate estate, all angers
Compar'd to his, to his—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let his, and all mens,
Whilst we have power and life: stand up for heaven sake.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have offended heaven too; yet heaven knows—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: We are all evill:
Yet heaven forbid we should have our deserts.
What is a?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Too too neare to my offence sir;
O he will cut me peece-meale.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Tis no Treason?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Let it be what it will: if a cut here,
Ile finde him cut-worke.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He must buy you deare,
With more than common lives.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Feare not, nor weep not:
By heaven Ile fire the Towne before yee perish,
And then, the more the merrier, wee'll jog with yee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come in, and dry your eyes.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Pray no more weeping:
Spoile a sweet face for nothing? my returne
Shall end all this I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Heaven grant it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This man should be of speciall rank:
For these commends carry no common way,
No slight worth with 'em:
A shall be he. Ent. Don Iohn.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: 'Save yee sir: I am sorrie
My businesse was so unmannerly, to make ye
Wait thus long here.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Occasions must be serv'd sir:
But is your name Don John?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: It is Sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Then,
First, for your owne brave sake I must embrace yee:
Next, from the credit of your noble friend
Hernando de Aluara, make yee mine:
Who layes his charge upon me in this Letter
To look yee out, and for the goodnesse in yee,
Whilst your occasions make yee resident
In this place, to supply yee, love and honour yee;
Which had I knowne sooner—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Noble sir,
You'll make my thanks too poore: I weare a sword, sir,
And have a service to be still dispos'd of,
As you shall please command it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gentle sir,
That manly courtesie is half my businesse:
And to be short, to make ye know I honour ye,
And in all points believe your worth like Oracle,
And how above my friends, which are not few,
And those not slack, I estimate your vertues,
Make your selfe understand, This day Petruchio,
A man that may command the strength of this place,
Hazzard the boldest spirits; hath made choice
Onely of you, and in a noble office.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Forward, I am free to entertaine it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thus then:
I doe beseech ye mark me.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I shall doe it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ferrara's Duke, would I might call him worthie,
But that he has raz'd out from his family,
As he has mine with Infamie, This man,
Rather this powerfull Monster, we being left
But two of all our house, to stock out memories,
My Sister, and my selfe; with arts, and witch-crafts,
Vowes, and such oathes heaven has no mercy for,
Drew to dishonour this weak maid, by stealthes,
And secret passages I knew not of,
Oft he obtain'd his wishes, oft abus'd her:
I am asham'd to say the rest: This purchas'd,
And his hot bloud allay'd, as friends forsake us
At a miles end upon our way, he left her,
And all our name to ruine.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: This was foule Play,
And ought to be rewarded so.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I hope so;
He scap'd me yester-night: which if he dare
Againe adventure for, heaven pardon him,
I shall with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: For me, brave Signior,
What doe yee intend?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Onely, faire sir, this trust,
Which from the commendations of this Letter,
I dare presume well placed, nobly to beare him
By word of mouth a single challenge from me,
That man to man, if he have honour in him,
We may decide all difference.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Faire, and noble,
And I will doe it home: When shall I visite ye?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Please you this after-noon, I will ride with yee:
For at a Castle six mile hence, we are sure
To finde him.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Ile be ready.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To attend ye,
My man shall wait: with all my Ex. Petr. Enter Fredr.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: My service shall not faile yee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: All's well: who dost thou think this wench is?
Ghesse, and thou canst?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Be it knowne then,
To all men by these presents, this is she,
She, she, and only she, our curious coxcombs
Were errant two moneths after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Who, Constantia?
Thou talk'st of Cocks and Bulls.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I talke of wenches,
Of Cocks and Hens Don Frerdick; this is the Pullet
We two went proud after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: It shall be;
Sister to Don Petruchio: I know all man.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now I beleeve.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Goe to, there has been stirring,
Fumbling with Linnen Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible,
You know her faine was pure as fire.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: That pure fire
Has melted out her maiden-head: she is crackt:
We have all that hope of our side, boy.

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.l: Thou tell'st me,
To my imagination, things incredible:
I see no loose thought in her.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: That's all one,
She is loose ith' hilts by heaven: but the world must know
A faire way, upon vow of marriage.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: There may be such a slip.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: And will be Fredrick,
Whil'st the old game's a foot: I feare the boy too
Will prove hers too I took up.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Good circumstance
May cure all this yet.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: There thou hitst it, Fredrick:
Come, let's walke in and comfort her: her being here
Is nothing yet suspected: anon Ile tell thee
Wherefore her brother came, who by this light
Is a brave noble fellow, and what honour
H'as done to me a stranger: there be Irons
Heating for some, will histe into their heart blouds,
'Ere all be ended; so much for this time.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Well sir Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Come ye doe know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I do not by this hand Mistris.
But I suspect.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: That if egges continue
At this price, women wil ne're be sav'd
By their good works.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yee shall, any thing
Lyes in my power: The Duke of Loraine now
Is seven thousand strong: I heard it of a fish-wife,
A woman of fine knowledge.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: The Popes Buls are broke loose too and 'tis suspected
They shall be baited in England.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, 'tis not so well neither.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: But I say to yee,
Who is it keeps your Master company?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say to you, Don Iohn.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I say what woman?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say so too.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I say againe, I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I say 'tis fit yee should.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And I tell thee
He has a woman here.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: And I tell thee
'Tis then the better for him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You are no Bawd now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Would I were able to be call'd unto it:
A worshipfull vocation for my elders;
For as I understand it is a place
Fitting my betters farr.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Was ever Gentlewoman
So frumpt off with a foole? well sawcy sirrah,
I will know who it is, and for what purpose;
I pay the rent, and I will know how my house
Comes by these Inflamations: if this geere hold,
Best hang a signe-post up, to tell the Signiors,
Here ye may have lewdnesse at Liverie. Ent. Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.l: 'Twould be a great ease to your age.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now?
Why what's the mater Land-lady?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What's the matter?
Ye use me decently among ye gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who has abus'd her, you sir?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: 'Ods my witnesse
I will not be thus treated, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I gave her no ill language.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Thou lyest lewdly,
Thou tookst me up at every word I spoke,
As I had been a Mawkin, a flurt Gillian;
And thou thinkst, because thou canst write & read,
Our noses must be under thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Dare you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Let but the truth be known Sir, I beseech ye,
She raves of wenches, and I know not what sir:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go to, thou know'st too well, thou wicked varlet,
Thou instrument of evill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: As I live Sir,
She is ever thus till dinner.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Get ye in,
Ile answer you anon sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: By this hand
Ile break your Possit pan. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Then by this hood
Ile lock the meat up.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now your grief, what is't?
For I can ghesse—

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ye may with shame enough,
If there were shame amongst yee; nothing thought on,
But how yee may abuse my house: not satisfi'd
With bringing home your Bastards to undoe me,
But you must drill your whores here too; my patience
Because I beare, and beare, and carry, all,
And as they say am willing to groan under)
Must be your make-sport now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No more of these words.
Nor no more murmurings Lady: for you know
That I know something. I did suspect your anger,
But turne it presently and handsomely,
And beare your selfe discreetly to this woman,
For such a one there is indeed.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: 'Tis well sonne.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Leaving your devils Matins, and your melanchollies,
Or we shall leave our lodgings.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: You have much need
To use these vagrant wayes, and to much profit:
Ye had that might content
(At home within your selves too) right good gentlemen,
Wholsome, and yee said handsome: But you gallants,
Boast that I was to beleeve ye—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Leave your suspicion:
For as I live there's no such thing.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Mine honour;
And 'twere not for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Come, your honour,
Your house, and you too, if you dare beleeve me
Are well enough: sleek up your self, leave crying, Bowle of wipe ready.
For I must have yee entertain this Lady
With all civility, she well deserves it,
Together with all secresie: I dare trust yee,
For I have found ye faithfull: when you know her
You will find your owne fault; no more words, but doe it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You know you may command me. Ent. Don. Ioh.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Worshipfull Lady,
How does thy Velvet scabbard? by this hand
Thou look'st most amiably: now could I willingly
And 'twere not for abusing thy Geneva print there,
Venture my body with thee.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You'll leave this roperie,
When you come to my yeares.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: By this light
Thou art not above fifteen yet, a meere girle,
Thou hast not half thy teeth: come—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prethee Iohn
Let her alone, she has been vex'd already:
Shee'll grow starke mad man.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I would see her mad,
An old mad woman

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prethee be patient.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Is like a Millers Mare, troubled with tooth-ache.
Shee'll make the rarest faces.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Goe, and doe it,
And doe not mind this fellow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Well Don John.
There will be times agen; when O good Mother,
What's good for a carnosity in the Bladder?
O the green water, mother.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Doting take yee,
Doe ye remember that?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She has payd ye now sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Clarry, sweet mother, Clarry.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Are ye satisfied?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ile never whore againe; never give Petticoats
And Wastcoats at five pound a peece; good Mother,
Quickly Mother: now mock on Son.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A devill grinde your old chaps. Exit Land.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: By this hand wench
Ile give thee a new hood for this.
Has she met with your Lordship?
Touch-wood rake her. Enter Anthony.
Shee's a rare ghostly mother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Below attends yee
The Gentlemans man sir that was with yee.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Well Sir;
My time is come then: yet if my project hold,
You shall not stay behinde: Ile rather trust. Enter Constan.
A Cat with sweet milk Fredrick; by her face
I feele her feares are working.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Is there no way,
I doe beseech yee think yet, to divert
This certaine danger?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible:
Their honours are engag'd.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then there must be murther,
Which, Gentlemen, I shall no sooner heare of,
Then make one int: you may, if you please sir,
Make all goe lesse yet.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Lady wer't mine owne cause,
I could dispence: but loaden with my friends trust,
I must go on; though generall massacres
As much I feare—

sp.speaker: Const,
sp.l: Doe ye heare sir; for heavens pittie
Let me request one love of you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes any thing.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This gentleman I find too resolute,
Too hot, and fiery for the cause, as ever
You did a vertuous deed, for honours sake
Go with him, and allay him: your fair temper
And noble disposition, like wish'd showres,
May quench those eating fires, that would spoile all else.
I see in him destruction.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will doe it;
And 'tis a wise consideration,
To me, a bounteous favour: harke ye John,
I will goe with yee.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Indeed I will,
Ye goe upon a hazard: no denyall;
For as I live, Ile goe.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Then make ye ready,
For I am straight a horse-back.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My sword on,
I am as ready as you: what my best labour,
With all the Art I have can work upon 'em,
Be sure of, and expect faire end: the old gentlewoman
Shall wait upon you; she is both grave and private,
And yee may trust her in all points.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Ye are noble:
And so I kisse your hand.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: That seale for me too,
And I hope happy issue Lady.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: All heavens care upon yee, and my prayers.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: So,
Now my mind's at rest.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Away, 'tis late John. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 2.
div.stage: Enter Antonio, a Surgeon, and 2. Gent.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Come sir, be hearty: all the worst is past.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give me some Wine.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: 'Tis death Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis a horse sir.
'Sbloud, to be drest to the tune of Ale onely,
Nothing but sawces to my sores.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Fie Antonio,
You must be govern'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Has given me a dam'd Glister,
Only of sand and snow water, gentlemen,
Has almost scour'd my guts out.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: I have giv'n you that sir
Is fittest for your state.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And here he feeds me
With rotten ends of rooks, and drown'd chickens,
Stewd Pericraniums, and Pia-maters;
And when I goe to bed, by heaven 'tis true gentlemen,
He rolls me up in Lints, with Labels at 'em,
That I am just the man ith' Almanack,
In head and face, is Aries place.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Wilt please ye
To let your friends see ye open'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will it please you sir
To let me have a wench: I feele my body
Open enough for that yet?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: How, a wench?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why look yee gentlemen; thus I am us'd still,
I can get nothing that I want.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Leave these things,
And let him open ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: De'ye heare Surgeon?
Send for the Musick, let me have some pleasure
To entertaine my friends, beside your Sallads,
Your green salves, and your searches, and some wine too,
That I may onely smell to it: or by this light
Ile dye upon thy hand, and spoyle thy custome.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Let him have Musick. Ent. Rowl. with wine.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: 'Tis ith' house, and ready,
If he will aske no more: but wine— Musick.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: He shall not drink it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Will these things please yee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and let 'em sing
John Dorrie.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis too long.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile have John Dorrie,
For to that warlike tune I will be open'd.
Give me some drinke, have yee stopt the leakes well Surgeon,
All will runne out else?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Feare not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sit downe Gentlemen:
And now advance your plaisters. Song of Joh. Dorry.
Give 'em ten shillings friends: how doe ye finde me?
What Symptomes doe you see now?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: None Sir, dangerous:
But if you will be rul'd—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What time?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: I can cure ye
In forty dayes, so you will not transgresse me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have a dog shall lick me whole in twenty:
In how long canst thou kill me?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe it; there's more delight in't.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: You must have patience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Man, I must have busines; this foolish fellow
Hinders himselfe: I have a dozen Rascalls
To hurt within these five dayes: good man mender,
Stop me up with Parsley, like stuft Beefe,
And let me walke abroad.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Ye shall walke shortly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For I must finde Petruchio.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Time enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Come lead him in, and let him sleep: within these three dayes
Wee'll beg yee leave to play.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: And then how things fall,
Wee'll certainly informe yee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But Surgion promise me
I shall drinke Wine then too.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: A little temper'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, Ile no tempering Surgion,

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Well, as't please ye,
So ye exceed not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell: and if ye finde
The Mad slave, that thus slasht me, commend me to him,
And bid him keep his skin close.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Take your rest sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have told yee all I can, and more then yet
Those Gentlemen know of me; ever trusting
Your Councell and concealement: for to me
You seem a worthy woman; one of those
Are seldome found in our sex, wise and vertuous,
Direct me I beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Ye say well Lady,
And hold yee to that poynt; for in these businesses
A womans councell that conceives the matter,
(Doe ye marke me, that conceives the matter Lady)
Is worth ten mens engagements: She knows something'
And out of that can worke like wax: when men
Are giddy-headed, either out of wine,
Or a more drunkennesse, vaine ostentation,
Discovering all: there is no more keep in 'em,
Then hold upon an Eeles taile: nay 'tis held fashion
To defame now all they can.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I, but these gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Doe not you trust to that: these gentlemen
Are as all Gentlemen of the same Barrell:
I, and the selfe same pickle too. Be it granted,
They have us'd yee with respect and faire behaviour,
Yet since ye came: doe you know what must follow?
They are Spaniards, Lady, Gennets of high mettle,
Things that will thrash the devill, or his dam,
Let 'em appeare but cloven.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now heaven blesse me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Mad Colts will court the wind: I know 'em Lady
To the least haire they have; and I tell you,
Old is I am, let but the pinte pot blesse 'em,
They'll offer to my yeares—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Such rude gambolls—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To you?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I, and so handle me, that oft I am forc'd
To fight of all foure for my safety: there's the yonger,
Don John, the arrantst Jack in all this City:
The other, time has blasted, yet he will stoop,
If not ore-flowne, and freely on the quarry;
Has been a Dragon in his dayes. Bur Tarmont,
Don Jenkin is the Devill himselfe, the Dog-dayes,
The most incomprehensible whore-master,
Twenty a night is nothing: Beggers, Broom-women,
And those so miserable, they look like famine,
Are all sweet Ladies in his drink.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's a handsome Gentleman.
Pitty he should be master of such follies.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Hee's ne're without a noise of Sirrenges
In's pocket, those proclame him; birding pills,
Waters to coole his conscience, in small Viols;
With thousand such sufficient emblemes: the truth is,
Whose chastity he chops upon, he cares not.
He flies at all; Bastards upon my conscience,
He has now in making multitudes; The last night
He brought home one; I pitty her that bore it,
But we are all weake vessels, some rich woman
(For wise I dare not call her) was the mother,
For it was hung with Jewels: the bearing cloath
No lesse then Crimson Velvet.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: 'Tis true Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Was it a Boy too?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: A brave Boy; deliberation
And judgement shewd in's getting, as I'le say for him,
He's as well paced for that sport—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: May I see it?
For there is a neighbour of mine, a Gentlewoman,
Has had a late mischance, which willingly
I would know further of; now if you please
To be so curteous to me.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Ye shall see it:
But what do ye thinke of these men now ye know 'em,
And of the cause I told ye of? Be wise,
Ye may repent too late else; I but tell ye
For your owne good, and as you will find it Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am advis'd.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: No more words then; do that,
And instantly, I told ye of be ready:
Don Iohn, I'le fit ye for your frumps,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I shall be:
But shall I see this Child?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Within this halfe houre,
Let's in, and there thinke better; she that's wise,
Leapes at occasion first; the rest pay for it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Don Iohn. and Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Sir, he is worth your knowledg; and a Gentleman
If I that so much love him, may commend him,
Of free and vertuous parts; and one, if soule play
Should fall upon us, for which feare I brought him,
Will not flie backe for phillips.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ye much honour me,
And once more I pronounce ye both mine.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stay, what Troope
Is that below i'th valley there?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Hawking I take it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: They are so; 'tis the Duke, 'tis even he Gentlemen,
Sirrah, draw backe the Horses till we call ye,
I know him by his company.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I thinke too
He bends up this way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: So he does.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Stand you still
Within that Covert till I call: you Fredrick,
By no meanes be not seen, unlesse they offer
To bring on odds upon us; he comes forward,
Here will I waite him fairely: to your Cabins.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I need no more instruct ye?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Feare me not,
I'le give it him, and boldly. Ex: Pet. and Fred.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Feed the Hawkes up,
Wee'l flie no more to day: O my blest fortune,
Have I so fairely met the man!

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Ye have Sir,
And him you know by this,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sir all the honour,
And love—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I do beseech your Grace stay there,
(For I know you too now) that love and honour
I come not to receive; nor can you give it,
Till ye appeare faire to the world; I must beseech ye
Dismisse your traine a little.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Walke aside,
And out of hearing I command ye: Now Sir,

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Last time we met, I was a friend.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And Nobly
You did a friends office: let your businesse
Be what it may, you must be still—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Your pardon,
Never a friend to him, cannot be friend
To his own honour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: In what have I transgress'd it?
Ye make a bold breach at the first Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Bolder,
You made that breach that let in infamy
And ruine, to surprize a noble stocke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be plaine Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I will, and short;
Ye have wrong'd a Gentleman
Little behind your selfe, beyond all justice,
Beyond mediation of all friends.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The man, and manner of wrong?
Iohn Petruchio,
The wrong, ye have whord his Sister.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What's his will in't?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: His will is to oppose you like a Gentleman,
And single, to decide all.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now stay you Sir,
And heare me with the like beliefe: this Gentleman
His Sister that you named, 'tis true I have long loved,
Nor was that love lascivious, as he makes it;
As true, I have enjoy'd her: no lesse truth
I have a child by her: But that she, or he,
Or any of that family are tainted
Suffer disgrace, or ruine, by my pleasures,
I weare a Sword to satisfie the world no,
And him in this cause when he please; for know Sir,
She is my wife, contracted before Heaven,
(Witnesse I owe more tye to, then her Brother)
Nor will I flye from that name, which long since
Had had the Churches approbation,
But for his jealous danger.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Sir, your pardon,
And all that was my anger, now my service.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Faire sir, I knew I should convert ye; had we
But that rough man herd now too—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: And ye shall Sir
Whoa, hoa, hoo.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I hope ye have laid no Ambush? Enter Petru.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Only friends.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My noble Brother welcome:
Come put your Anger off, we'l have no fighting,
Unlesse you will maintaine I am unworthy
To beare that name.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Do you speake this hartely?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: upon my soule, and truly; the first Priest
Shall put you out of these doubts.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now I love ye;
And I beseech you pardon my suspitions,
You are now more then a Brother, a brave friend too.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The good man's over-joyd Enter Fred.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now, how goes it?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why, the man 'has his mare agen, and all's well Fredrick,
The Duke professes freely hee's her husband.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Yes, for modest Gentlemen.
I must present ye: may it please your Grace
To number this brave Gentleman, my friend
And noble kinsman, amongst those your servants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O my brave friend! you showre your bounties on me
Amongst my best thoughts Signior, in which number
You being worthily dispos'd already,
May place your friend to honour me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My love sir,
And where your Grace dares trust me, all my service.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why? this is wondrous happy: But now Brother,
Now comes the bitter to our sweet: Constantia.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why, what of her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor what, nor where, do I know?
Wing'd with her feares last night, beyond my knowledge,
She quit my house, but whether—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let not that—

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more good Sir, I have heard too much.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay sinke not,
She cannot be so lost.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Nor shall not Gentlemen;
Be free agen, the Ladie's found; that smile Sir,
Shewes ye distruct your Servant.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I do beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Ye shall beleeve me: by my soule she is safe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heaven knows, I would beleeve Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye may safely.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: And under noble usage: this faire Gentleman
Met her in all her doubts last night, and to his guard
(Her feares being strong upon her) she gave her person,
who waited on her, to our lodging; where all respect,
Civill and honest service now attend her.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: Ye may beleeve now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes, I do, and strongly:
Well my good friends, or rather my good Angels,
For ye have both preserved me; when these vertues
Dye in your friends remembrance—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Good your grace
Lose no more time in complement, 'tis too pretious,
I know it by my selfe, there can be no hell
To his that hangs upon his hopes; especially
In way of lustly pleasures.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He has hit it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: To horse againe then, for this night I'le crowne
With all the joyes ye wish for.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Happy Gentlemen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This is the maddest mischiefe: never foole
Was so fubd off, as I am; made ridiculous,
And to my selfe, mine owne Asse: trust a woman,
I'le trust the Devill first; for he dare be
Better then's word sometime: what faith have I broke?
In what observance failed? Let me consider, Enter Don Iohn. and Fred.
For this is monstrous usage.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let them talke,
Wee'll ride on faire and softly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well Constantia,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Constantia, what's this fellow? stay by all means.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ye have spun your selfe a faire thred now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stand still Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What cause had you to fly? what feare possest ye?
Were you not safely lodg'd from all suspition?
Us'd with all gentle meanes? did any know
How ye came thether, or what your sin was.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Iohn.
smell some juggling John.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Yes, Fredricks, I feare it will be found so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So strangely,
Without the counsell of your friends; so desperatly
To put all dangers on ye?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis she.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So deceitfully
After a strangers lure?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Did ye marke that Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: To make ye appeare more monster; and the Law
More cruell to reward ye? to leave all,
All that should be your safegard, to seeke evils?
Was this your wisedome? this your promise? well
He that incited ye—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Marke that too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Had better have plough'd farther off; now Lady,
What will your last friend, he that should preserve ye,
And hold your credit up, the brave Antonio,
Thinke of this slip? he'll to Petruchio,
And call for open justice.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: 'Tis she Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But what that he is John.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do not doubt yet
To bolt ye out, for I know certainly
Ye are about the Towne still: ha, no more words. Ex.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Discreetly.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Finely carried.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have no more of these tricks?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Ten to one Sir,
I shall meet with 'em if ye have.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Is this honest?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Was it in you a friends part to deale double?
I am no asse Don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And Don Iohn,
It shall appeare I am no foole;
Disgrace me to make yourselfe a lecher?
'Tis boyish, 'tis base.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: 'Tis false, and most unmanly to upbraid me,
Nor will I be your bolster Sir,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou wanton boy, thou hadst better have been Eunuch,
Thou common womans curtesie, then thus
Lascivious, basely to have bent mine honour.
A friend? I'le make a horse my friend first!

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Holla, holla,
Ye kicke to fast sir: what strange braines have you got,
That dare crow out thus bravely? I better been a Eunuch?
I privy to this dog tricke? cleare your selfe,
For I know where the wind sits, and most nobly,
Or as I have a life—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No more: they'r horses. A noyse within like horses.
Nor shew no discontent: to morrow comes;
Let's quietly away: if she be at home,
Our jealousies are put off.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The fellow Enter Duke, Petruchio.
We have lost him in our spleenes, like fooles.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come Gentlemen,
Now set on roundly; suppose ye have all mistresses,
And mend your pace according,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then have at ye. Exeunt

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio, Fredrick, and Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: NOw to Bollonia, my most honoured brother,
I dare pronounce yea hearty, and safe welcome,
Our loves shall now way-lay ye; welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The same to you brave Sir; Don Fredrick
Will ye step in, and give the Lady notice
Who comes to honour her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Bid her be suddain,
We come to see no curious wench: a night-gowne
Will serve the turne: here's one that knowes her neerer.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I'le tell her what ye say Sir. Ex. Fred.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My deare brother,
Ye are a merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now will the sport be
To observe her alterations; how like wildfire
She'll leap into your bosome; then seeing me,
Her conscience, and her feares creeping upon her
Dead as a fowle at souse, she'll sinke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Faire brother,
I must entreat you—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I conceive your mind Sir,
I will not chide her: yet ten duckets Duke,
She falls upon he knees, ten more she dare not—

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I must not have her frighted.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well you shall not: Enter Fred. and Peter.
But like a summers evening against heate,
Marke how I'le guild he cheekes?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: How now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye may Sir:
Not to abuse your patience, noble friends,
Nor hold ye off with tedious circumstance,
For you must know,—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What did you say Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gone, by heaven removed,
The woman of the house too.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Well Don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Don Iohn, it is not well, but—
