sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This fellow
Can testifie I lye not.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Some foure houres after
My Master was departed with this Gentleman,
My fellow and my selfe, being sent of businesse,
(As we must thinke) of purpose—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Hang these circumstances,
They appeare like owles, to ill ends.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Now could I eate
The devil in his own broath, I am so tortur'd.
Gone?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Directly gone, fled, shifted: what would you have me say?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well Gentlemen,
Wrong not my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For your Dukedome
I will not be a knave Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: He that is
A rot run in his bloud.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: But harke ye Gentlemen,
Are ye sure ye had her here, did ye not dreame this.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Have you your nose Sir?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Then we had her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Since you are so short, beleeve your having her
Shall suffer more construction.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Let it suffer,
But if I be not cleere of all dishonour,
Or practice that may taint my reputation,
And ignorant of where this woman is,
Make me your Cities monster.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I beleeve ye.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I could lye with a witch now, to be reveng'd
Upon that Rascall did this.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Only thus much
I would desire your Grace, for my minde gives me
Before night yet she is yours: stop all opinion,
And let no anger out, till full cause call it,
Then every mans owne work's to justifie him,
And this day let us give to search: my man here
Tels me, by chance he saw out of a window
(Which place he has taken note of) such a face
As our old Landladies, he beleeves the same too,
And by her hood assures it: Let's first thether,
For she being found, all's ended.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come, for heavens sake,
And Fortune, and thou beest not ever turning,
If there be one firme step in all thy reelings,
Now settle it, and save my hopes: away friends. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With all my jewels?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: All Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And that money
I left i'th' trunke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Trunke broke, and that gone too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Franscisco of the plot?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Gone with the wench too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The mighty poxe go with 'em: belike they thought
I was no man of this world, and those trifles
Would but disturbe my conscience.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sure they thought Sir,
You would not live to persecute 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whore and Fidler,
Why, what a consort have they made? Hen and bacon?
Well my sweet Mistris, well good Madam martaile?
You that have hung about my neck, and lick't me,
I'le try how handsomely your Ladyship
Can hang upon a Gallowes, there's your Master-piece;
But harke ye Sirrah, no imagition Bawd ready above.
Of where they should be?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: None Sir, yet we have search'd
All places we suspected; I beleeve Sir,
They have taken towards the Ports.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Get me a conjurer,
One that can raise a water devill, I'le port 'em;
Play at duck and drake with my money? take heed Fidler;
I'le dance ye by this hand, your Fidle-sticke
I'le grease of a new fashion, for presuming
To medle with my degamboys: get me a Conjurer,
Enquire me out a man that lets out devils:
None but my C. Cliffe serve your turne?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I know not—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In every street, Tom foole, any bleare-eyd people
With red heads, and flat noses can performe it;
Thou shalt know 'em by their half gowns & no breeches:
Mount my mare Fidler? ha boy? up at first dash?
Sit sure, I'le clap a nettle, and a smart one,
Shall make your filly firck: I will find Fidler,
I'le put you to your plundge boy: Sirrah meet me
Some two houres hence at home; In the meane time
Find out a conjurer and know his price,
How he will let his devils by the day out,
I'le have 'em, and they be above ground. Exit Ant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now blesse me,
What a mad man is this? I must do something
To please his humour: such a man I'le aske for,
And tell him where he is: but to come neare him,
Or have any thing to do with his don devills,
I thanke my feare, I dare not, nor I will not. Exit.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio, Fredrick, John, Peter, Servant with bottles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Whether wilt thou lead us?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis hard by sir.
And ten to one this wine goes thether.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Are they growne so merry.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis most likely
She has heard of this good fortune, and determines
To wash her sorrowes off.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis so; that house sir
Is it: out of that window certainly
I saw my old Mistrisses face.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: They are merry indeed, Musicke.
Harke I here Musicke too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Excellent Musick.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Would I were ev'n among 'em and alone how,
A pallat for the purpose in a corner,
And good rich wine within me; what gay sport
Could I make in an houre now? Song.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Harke a voice too;
Let's not stir yet by any meanes.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Was this her owne voyce?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes sure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare one. Enter Bawd (above)

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The Song confirmes her here too: for if ye marke it,
It spake of liberty, and free enjoying
The happy end of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Looke ye there sir,
Do ye know that head?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis my good Landlady,
I find feare has done all this.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Shee I sweare,
And now do I know by the hanging of her hood,
She is parcell drunke: shall we go in?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Not yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, let 'em take their pleasure,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: When it is highest, Musicke.
Wee'll step in, and amaze 'em: peace more Musicke.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: This Musick murders me; what bloud have I now?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I should know that face. Enter Fran. and Exit.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: By this light 'tis he Fredricks,
That bred our first suspitions, the same fellow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He that we overtooke, and overheard too
Discoursing of Constantia.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Still the same;
Now he slips in.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She must be here Sir:
This is the very fellow, I told your Grace Enter Fran.
We found upon the way; and what his talke was.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why, sure I know this fellow; yes, 'tis he,
Francisco, Antonio's Boy, a rare Musitian,
He taught my Sister on the Lute, and is ever
(She loves his voice so well) about her: certaine,
Without all doubt she is here: it must be so.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Here? that's no question: what should our hen o'th game else
Do here without her? if she be not here
(I am so confident) let your Grace beleeve,
We two are arrant Rascalls, and have abus'd ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I say so too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Why there's the hood againe now,
The guard that guides us; I know the fabricke of it.
And know the old tree of that saddle yet, 'twas made of
A hunting hood, observe it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Who shall enter?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I'le make one.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I, another.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But so carry it,
That all her joyes flow not together.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: If we told her,
Your Grace would none of her?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: By no meanes Signior,
'Twould turne her wild, starke frantick.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Or assur'd her—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nothing of that? starve nature? this ye may sir.
That the conditions of our feare yet stand
On nyce and dangerous knittings: or that a little
I seeme to doubt the child.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Would I could draw her
To hate your Grace with these things.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come let's enter, Exit. Pet. and Ioh. Musick.
And now he sees me not, I'le search her soundly.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now lucke of all sides.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: Doubt it not: more Musicke:
Sure she has heard some comfort.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes, stand still sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is the maddest song.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Applyed for certaine Claping of a doore.
To some strange mellancholly she is loden with.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now all the sport begins— harke?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: They are amongst'em,
The feares now, and the shakings? Trampling above.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Our old Lady
(Harke how they run) is euen now at this instant Cease Musick Petr. and Iohn within.
Ready to loose her head peice by Don Iohn,
Or creeping through a Cat hole.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bring 'em downe,
And you sir, follow me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hee's angry with 'em,
I must not suffer this.
Bowle downe the Bawd there Iohn within.
Old Erra mater: you Lady leachery
For the good will I beare to'th game, most tenderly
Shall be lead out, and lash'd.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Iohn, Whore, and Bawd, with Francisco.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is this Constantia?
Why Gentlemen? what do you meane? is this she?

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: I am Constantia sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A Whore ye are sir.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: 'Tis very true: I am a Whore indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She will not lye yet, though she steale.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: A plaine whore,
If you please to imploy me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And an impudent—

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: Plaine dealing now is impudence.
One if you will sir, can shew ye as much sport
In one halfe houre, and with as much variety,
As a far wiser woman can in halfe a yeare:
For there my way lies.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is she not drunk too?

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: A little guilded o're sir,
Old sack, old sacke boyes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This is saliant.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: A brave bold queane.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is this your certainty?
Do ye know the man ye wrong thus, Gentlemen?
Is this the woman meant?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That your Landlady?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Am I a person
To be your sport Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I do beleeve now certaine
I am a knave; but how, or when—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bawd to this peece of pye meat.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: A poore Gentlewoman
That lyes in Towne, about Law businesse,
And't like your worships.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You shall have Law, beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: I'le shew your mastership my case.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: By no meanes,
I had rather see a Custard.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: My dead husband
Left it even thus sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Blesse mine eyes from blasting,
I was never so frighted with a case.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: And so sir—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Enough, put up good velvet head.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What are you two now,
By your owne free confessions?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What you shall thinke us,
Though to my selfe I am certaine, and my life
Shall make that good and perfect, or fall with it.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We are sure of nothing (Fred) that's the truth on't:
I do not think my nam's Don John, nor dare not
Beleeve any thing that concernes me, but my debts,
Nor those in way of payment: things are so carried,
What to entreat your Grace, or how to tell ye
We are, or we are not, is past my cunning,
But I would faine imagine we are honest,
And o' my conscience, I should fight in't—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thus then,
For we may be all abus'd.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis possible,
For how should this concerne them?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here let's part—
Untill to morrow this time: we to our way,
To make this doubt out, and you to your way;
Pawning our honours then to meet againe,
When if she be not found.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We stand engaged
To answer any worthy way we are cald to.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We aske no more.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: Ye have done with us then?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No Dame.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But is her name Constantia?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes a moveable
Belonging to a friend of mine: come out Fidler,
What say you to this Lady; be not fearfull?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Saving the reverence of my Masters pleasure,
I say she is a whore, and that she has robb'd him,
Hoping his hurts would kill him.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: Who provok't me?
Nay sirrah squeak, Ile see your treble strings
Ty'd up too; if I hang, Ile spoyle your piping,
Your sweet face shall not save yee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thou dam'd impudence,
And thou dry'd devill; where's the Officer?

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Hee's here sir. Enter Officer.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Lodge these safe till I send for 'em;
Let none come to 'em, nor no noise be heard
Of where they are, or why: away.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: By this hand
A handsome whore: Now will I be arrested,
And brought home to this officers: a stout whore,
I love such stirring ware: pox o' this businesse,
A man must haunt out morsells for another,
And starve himself: a quick-ey'd whore, that's wild-fire,
And makes the bloud dance through the veines like billowes.
I will reprive this whore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, good luck with ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: As much attend your Grace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To morrow certaine—

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: If we out-live this night sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come Don John,
We have something now to doe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I am sure I would have.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If she be not found, we must fight.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I am glad on't,
I have not fought a great while.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If we dye—

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Ther's so much money sav'd in lecherie. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio below, and Vechio above.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: IT should be here abouts.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Your grace is right,
This is the house I know it.

sp.speaker: Voch.
sp.l: Grace?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis further
By the description we received.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Good my Lord the Duke,
Believe me, for I know it certainly,
This is the very house.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: My Lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Pray heaven this man Prove right now.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Beleeve it, hee's a most sufficient Scholler,
And can doe rare tricks this way; for a figure,
Or raising an appearance, whole Christendome
Has not a better; I have heard strange wonders of him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But can he shew us where she is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Most certaine,
And for what cause too she departed.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Knock then,
For I am great with expectation,
Till this man satisfie me: I feare the Spaniards,
Yet they appeare brave fellowes: can he tell us?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: With a wet finger, whether they be false.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Who's within here? Enter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your Grace may enter.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How can he know me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He knowes all.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And you sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: What do you call his name?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why, Peter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: They say he can raise devills,
Can he make 'em
Tell truth too, when he has rais'd 'em? for beleeve it,
These devils are the lyingst Rascalls.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He can compell 'em.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: With what? can he
Tye squibs in their tailes, and fire the truth out?
Or make 'em eate a bawling Puritan,
Whose sanctified zeale shall rumble like an Earthquake?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: With Spels man?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I with spoones as soone, dost thou thinke
The devill such an Asse as people make him?
Such a poore coxcomb? such a penny foot post?
Compel'd with crosse and pile to run of errands?
With Asteroth, and Behemoth, and Belfagor?
Why should he shake at sounds, that lives in a smiths forg?
Or if he do—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Without all doubt he do's Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why should not Bilbo raise him, or a paire of bullyons,
They go as big as any? or an unshod Car,
When he goes tumble, tumble o're the stones,
Like Anacreons drunken verses, make us tremble?
These make as fell a noyse; me thinkes the collick
Well handled, and fed with small beere—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis the vertue—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The vertue? nay, and goodnesse fetch him up once,
Has lost a friend of me; the wise old Gentleman
Knowes when, and how; I'le lay this hand to two pence,
Let all the Conjurers in Christendome,
With all their spells, and vertues call upon him,
And I but thinke upon a wench, and follow it,
He shall be sooner mine then theirs; where's vertue?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou art the most sufficient, (I'le say for thee)
Not to beleeve a thing—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: O sir, slow credit
Is the best child of knowledge; I'le go with ye,
And if he can do any thing, I'le thinke
As you would have me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let's enquire along,
For certaine we are not far off.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Nor much nearer. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 3.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: You lost her yesternight.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: How thinke you sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is your name Vechio?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And you can shew me
These; things you promise.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your graces word bound to me,
No hand of Law shall seize me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: As I live sir—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And as I live, that can do something too sir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I take your promises: stay here a little,
Till I prepare some Ceremonies, and I'le satisfie ye.
The Ladies name's Constantia?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I come straight. Exit Vech.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sure hee's a learned man.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The most now living;
Did your grace marke when we told all these circumstances,
How ever and anon he bolted from us
To use his studies helpe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now I thinke rather
To talke with some familiar.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Not unlikely,
For sure he has 'em subject.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How could he else
Tell when she went, and who went with her?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Or hit upon mine honour: or assure me
The Lady lov'd me dearely?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twas so.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Now,
I do beseech your Grace sit downe, and you sir;
Nay pray sit close like brothers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A rare fellow.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And what ye see, stir not at, nor use a word,
Untill I aske ye; for what shall appeare
Is but weake apparition and thin ayre
Not to be held, nor spoken too. Knocking within.

div.stage: John, Frederick, and a Servant within.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We are counselled—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: What noise is that without there?

sp.speaker: Fred. Within.
sp.l: We must speake with him.

sp.speaker: Ser. Within.
sp.l: Hee's busie Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iohn. Within.
sp.l: That's all one friend,
We must, and will speake with him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let 'em in sir,
We know their tongues and businesse, 'tis our owne,
And in this very cause that we now come for,
They also come to be instructed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Let 'em in then:
Sit down, I know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Duke before us,
Now we shall sure know something.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Not a question,
But make your eyes, your tongues—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: This is a strange jugler,
Neither indent before hand for his payment,
Nor know the breadth of the businesse; sure his devell
Comes out of Lapland were they sell men winds,
For dead drinke, and old doublets.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Let him, he cannot raise my devill.

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.l: Prethee peace.

lg.l: And you soft winds so cleare,
That dance upon the leaves, and make them sing
With your verdure as ye blow,
Raise these formes from under ground
With a soft and happy sound.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: This is an honest Conjurer, and a pretty Poet;
I like his words well, there's no bumbast in 'em,
But do you thinke now, he can cudgell up the devill,
With this short staffe of Verses?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Peace the spirits— 2. Shapes of women passe by.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Nay, and they be no worse—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Do ye know these faces?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit still upon your lives then: and marke what follows:
Away, away.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: These devils do not paint sure?
Have they no sweeter shapes in hell? Constantia passes by.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Harke now Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I marry, this moves something like, this devill
Carries some metall in her gate.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I find ye,
You would see her face unvail'd?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Be uncovered.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: See how she blushes.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Fredrick,
This devill for my money; this is she Boy,
Why thou shake? I burne.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit still, and silent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She lookes back at me; now she smiles sir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I must rise, or burst. Exit. Const.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Ye see what followes—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O gentle sir this shape agen.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I cannot,
'Tis all disolv'd againe: this was the figure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The very same sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No hope once more to see it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: You might have kept it longer, had ye spar'd it,
Now 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No meanes to find it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Yes that there is: sit still a while, there's wine
To thaw the wonder from your hearts: drinke well sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: This Conjurer is a right good fellow too,
A lad of mettle; two such devils more
Would make me a Conjurer: what wine is it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hollock.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: The devil's in it then, looke how it dances?
Well, if I be—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: We are all before ye,
That's your best comfort sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: byth' mas brave wine;
Nay, and the Devils live in this hell, I dare venture
Within these two months yet to be delivered
Of a large legion of 'em. Enter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here 'a comes,
Silence of all sides Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vec.
sp.l: Good your grace,
Observe a stricter temper, and you too gallants,
You'l be deluded all else. This merry devill
That next appeares, for such a one you'l find it,
Must be cal'd up by a strange incantation,
A Song, and I must sing it: pray beare with me,
And pardon my rude pipe; for yet ere parting
Twenty to one I please ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We are arm'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor shall you see us more transgresse.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What think'st thou
Now Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why, now do I thinke Fredrick,
(And it I thinke amisse heaven pardon me,)
This honest Conjurer, with some foure or five
Of his good fellow devils, and my selfe,
Shall be yet drunke ere midnight. Song.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why, this is the Song Fredrick: twenty pound now
To see but our Don Gillian.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace it appeares.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I cannot peace: devils in French hoods Fredrick?
Sathans old Siringes?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: She, Boy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What dost thou meane?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: She, Boy, I say.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: She, boy.
The very child too Fredrick;

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She laughes on us
Aloud Iohn, has the devill these affections?
I do beleeve 'tis she indeed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Stand still.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I will not;
Who calls Jeronimo from his naked bed?
Sweet Lady, was it you? If thou beest the devill,
First, having crost my selfe, to keep out wildfire,
Then said some speciall prayers to defend me
Against thy most unhallowed hood: have at thee.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Hold sir, I am no devill.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am your very Landlady.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I defie thee:
Thus as St. Dunstan blew the devils nose
With a paire of tongs, even so right worshipfull—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Sweet son, I am old Gillion.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This is no spirit.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Art thou old Gillian, flesh and bone?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am Son.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.p: Sit still sir, now I'le shew you all. Ex. Vech.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Where's thy bottle?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Here, I beseech ye son—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: For I know the devill
Cannot assume that shape.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Tis she Iohn, certaine—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: A hogs poxe o'your mouldy chaps, what make you
Tumbling and juggling here?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am quit now Signior,
For all the prankes you plaid, and railings at me,
For to tell true, out of a trick I put
Upon your high behaviours, which was a lye,
But then it serv'd my turne, I drew the Lady
Unto my kinsmans here, only to torture
Your Don-ships for a day or two; and secure her
Out of all thoughts of danger: here she comes now.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May I yet speake?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes, and embrace her too,
For one that loves you deerer—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O my sweetest.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Blush not, I will not chide ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: To add more
Unto the joy I know, I bring ye, see sir,
The happy fruit of all our vowes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Heavens blessing
Be round about thee ever.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Pray blesse me to,
For if your grace be well instructed this way,
You'l find the keeping halfe the getting.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I'le tell ye that anon.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: 'Tis true this Gentleman
'Has done a charity worthy your favour,
And let him have it deare sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My best Lady
She has, and ever shall have: so must you sir,
To whom I am equall bound, as to my being.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Your Graces humble servants—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why kneele you sir?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: For pardon for my boldnesse: yet 'twas harmlesse
And all the art I have sir; those your grace saw
Which you thought spirits, were my neighbours children
Whom I instruct in Grammer, here, and Musick;
Their shapes, the peoples fond opinions,
Beleeving I can conjure, and oft repairing
To know of things stolne from 'em, I keepe about me,
And alwaies have in readinesse; by conjecture
Out of their owne confessions, I oft tell 'em
Things, that by chance have fallen out so: which way
(Having the persons here, I knew you sought for)
I wrought upon your grace: my end is mirth,
And pleasing, if I can, all parties.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I beleeve it,
For you have pleas'd me truly: so well pleas'd me,
That when I shall forget it—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Here's old Antonio,
I spide him at a window, comming mainely
I know about his whore, the man you light on,
As yon discovered unto me: good your Grace,
Let's stand by all, 'twill be a mirth above all,
To observe his pelting fury.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: About a wench sir?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A young whore that has rob'd him,

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: But do you know sir,
Where she is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, and will make that perfect—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I am instructed well then.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: If he come
To have a devill shew'd him, by all meanes
Let me be he, I can rore rarely.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Be so,
But take heed to his anger.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Slip in quickly,
There you shall find suites of all sorts: when I call,
Be ready and come forward. Ex. all but Vech.
Who's there come in?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you the Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sir I can do a little
That way, if you please to imploy me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Presently shew me a devill that can tell—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Where your wench is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are i'th' right; as also where the Fidler
That was consenting to her.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit ye there sir,
Ye shall know presently: can ye pray heartily?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, is your devill so furious?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I must shew ye
A forme, may chance affright ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He must fart fire then:
Take you no care for me.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Ascend Asterth, Enter Don John like a Spirit.
Why, when, appeare I say— Now question him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is my whore Don devill?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Gone to China,
To be the great Chams Mistris.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That's a lye devill:
Where are my jewels?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Pawn'd for Peticoates.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That may be; where's the Fidler?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Condemn'd to th' Gallowes,
For robbing of a Mill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The lyingst devill
That e're I dealt withall, and the unlikeliest:
What was that Rascall hurt me?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who was he?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye here conjurer,
Dare you venture your devill?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I'le venture my dagger;
Have at your devils pate; do ye mew? Enter all.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hold there,
I do command ye hold.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is this the devill?
Why Conjurer—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Has been a devill to you sir.
But now you shall forget all: your whores safe,
And all your Jewels: your Boy too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Now the devill indeed
Lay his ten claws upon thee, for my pate
Finds what it is to be a fend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All safe?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pray ye know this person: all's right now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your grace
May now command me then: but where's my whore?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Ready to goe to whiping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My whore whipt?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, your whore without doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whipt? pray Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why, would you have her once more rob ye? the young boy
You may forgive, he was intic'd.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The Whore sir,
Would rather carry pitty: a hansome Whore.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Gentleman I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Let's in all.
And if we see contrition in your whore sir,
Much may be done.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now my deare faire, to you,
And the full consummation of my Vow.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: APtnesse for mirth to all, this instant night
Thalia hath prepar'd for your delight,
Her choice and curious Viands, in each part,
Season'd with rarities of wit, as Art;
Nor feare I to be tax'd for a vaine boast,
My promise will finde credit with the most,
When they know Ingenuous Fletcher made it, hee
Being in himselfe a perfect Comedie.
And some sit here, I doubt not dare a verre,
Living he made that house a Theater
Which he pleas'd to frequent; and thus much we
Could not but pay to his loud memorie.
For our selves we doe entreat that you would not
Expect strange turnes, and windings in the Plot,
Objects of State, and now and then a Rhime,
To gall particular persons, with the time;
Or that his to wring Muse hath made her flight
Nearer your apprehension then your sight:
But if that sweet expressions, quick conceit,
Familiar language, fashion'd to the weight
Of such as speake it, have the power to raise
Your grace to us, with Trophies to his praise:
We may professe, presuming on his skill,
If his Chances please not you, our fortune's ill.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: WE have not held you long, nor doe I see
One brow in this selected company
Assuring a dislike, our paines were eas'd.
Could we be confident that all rise pleas'd:
But such ambition soares too high: If wee
Have satisfi'd the best, and they agree
In a faire censure, We have our reward;
And in them arm'd, desire no surer guard.
